body.p: Richardson, the Vicar–designate of Pelton, came to lunch. I arranged to institute him Wednesday, May 15th. He was evidently pleased at the prospect of independent work. The state of the Church in Pelton would appear to be deplorable, for no more than 10 children attended the children's service. The population is about 10,000.
Dr Short, the Vicar of Kelloe, came to ask me to dedicate a memorial window in his parish church. It has been erected by Wood to the memory of his sister. I promised to do so on Palm Sunday evening.

Alfre Toomey came to tea, & to tell me that the doctor advised him to go to a specialist in Newcastle, & be examined. I fear that his health is going to become a grievous handicap on his clerical career. It is a great pity, for he seems to have the makings of an excellent clergyman.

p.hi: wrote to me from Keble College. He has been attending the Mission to undergraduates, which Archbishop Temple is conducting, & seems to have been greatly impressed. The Warden of Keble has allotted to him a small prize for his English work, & he is much exalted. He sends me his photograph. He is certainly one of the most promising of the Ordination candidates. He will not be ready for Ordination before 1932.
